module.name: renderer

details.p: The `Window` interface defines the contract for window creation and management inside the framework. Each window instance operates in isolation, backed by its own `lua_State`, similar in spirit to Electron processes. This ensures complete separation of state and scripts across windows, avoiding unintended side effects between them.
The main application script `main.lua` is responsible for creating and managing windows. Once created, each window runs independently, maintaining its own Lua environment and bindings.

The event loop for windows is cooperative and integrated with the core runtime. Events are dispatched and processed in a manner similar to how native windowing systems propagate events, while remaining script-driven and cross-platform within the engine.

enums.name: TextureFilter

enums.enum: Uses nearest-neighbor sampling for sharp, pixelated appearance.
Uses bilinear interpolation for smooth texture sampling.
Uses trilinear interpolation with mipmap blending for high-quality filtered textures.

enums.summary: Defines texture coordinate wrapping behavior at texture boundaries.
enums.enum: Clamps texture coordinates to [0, 1] range, repeating edge pixels beyond boundaries.

enums.name: TextureFormat
enums.summary: Defines the internal pixel format for texture storage.
enums.enum: Uses default format from project settings, typically Rgba8 for standard color textures.
Four-channel 8-bit format with red, green, blue, and alpha components (32 bits per pixel).
Three-channel 8-bit format with red, green, and blue components only (24 bits per pixel).
Single-channel 8-bit format containing only alpha (transparency) values.
Single-channel depth format for depth buffer rendering and shadow mapping.
Combined depth and stencil format for advanced rendering techniques requiring both depth testing and stencil operations.

enums.name: MipmapMode
enums.enum: Only the base (highest-resolution) mip level is used. Fastest, but can cause aliasing when textures are minified.
Selects the nearest mip level based on the distance, without blending between levels. Produces sharper but less smooth transitions.
Interpolates between two nearest mip levels for smoother transitions. Common default for high-quality rendering.
Performs linear filtering across both texel and mip levels, providing the smoothest possible texture transitions (slightly slower).

enums.name: AnisotropyType
enums.enum: Disables anisotropic filtering. Texture detail will degrade at oblique viewing angles.
Applies 2x anisotropic filtering, modestly improving texture clarity at shallow angles.
Applies 4x anisotropic filtering, balancing performance and quality.
Applies 8x anisotropic filtering for high-quality rendering with moderate cost.
Applies 16x anisotropic filtering for the sharpest textures at glancing angles, at higher GPU cost.

component.name: Texture
component.summary: Base class for managing texture resources and their sampling parameters for rendering.
component.details: Controls texture image loading, filtering modes, and coordinate wrapping behavior. Supports texture preprocessing options like premultiplication and scaling for optimized rendering performance. Serves as the foundation for specialized texture types such as SingleTexture and RenderTargetTexture.
component.property: Filtering method used when texture is rendered smaller than its original size.
Filtering method used when texture is rendered larger than its original size.
Defines how texture coordinates outside [0, 1] range are handled.
Specifies the internal pixel format and channel layout used for texture storage in GPU memory.

Scale factor for high-DPI display support. Indicates the pixel density multiplier (e.g., 1 for standard displays, 2 for Retina/2x displays, 3 for 3x displays). The texture is loaded at higher resolution and scaled down for rendering on high-DPI screens.
Controls how mipmaps are sampled when rendering the texture. Higher modes like `Linear` and `Trilinear` yield smoother transitions at the cost of performance.
Defines the anisotropic filtering level applied to the texture. Improves clarity at shallow view angles; higher values offer better quality with greater GPU cost.
component.field: macOS-specific handle to an IOSurface object for zero-copy texture sharing between processes and frameworks.
OpenGL texture object identifier assigned by the GPU driver.
OpenGL framebuffer object identifier for render-to-texture operations.
OpenGL depth buffer (renderbuffer) object identifier for depth testing when rendering to this texture.
component.property: Actual width of the texture in pixels.
Actual height of the texture in pixels.

enums.name: ImageFormat
enums.enum: Portable Network Graphics — lossless compression, supports alpha channel, widely used for UI textures and screenshots
Joint Photographic Experts Group — lossy compression, smaller file sizes, no full alpha support, suitable for photos
Scalable Vector Graphics — vector format, resolution-independent, ideal for icons, logos, and UI elements that need to scale without loss

Adaptive Scalable Texture Compression — block-based GPU texture compression format supporting lossy and near-lossless modes, with alpha channel support. Optimized for real-time rendering and mobile/embedded GPUs.

PowerVR Texture Compression — hardware texture compression format optimized for PowerVR GPUs (common in iOS devices). Provides efficient storage with optional alpha support, suitable for mobile real-time graphics.

component.name: RenderTargetTexture
component.summary: Texture configured as a render target for off-screen rendering and post-processing effects.
component.details: Extends the base Texture class to create a dynamic texture that can be bound as a framebuffer for rendering operations. Supports custom dimensions for targeted resolutions, enabling techniques like bloom, depth-of-field, or shadow mapping without affecting the main display output.
component.property: The desired width in pixels for the render target texture, determining the horizontal resolution of rendered content.
The desired height in pixels for the render target texture, determining the vertical resolution of rendered content.
Specifies which kind of render target this texture represents — for example, a color, depth, or stencil attachment.
Enables use of a simplified render target setup — typically a single color buffer without depth or stencil attachments, used for lightweight or offscreen rendering tasks.
Defines the framebuffer slot or channel this texture is attached to.
Allows using a depth-only buffer as a fallback when a full depth-stencil attachment is unavailable, ensuring rendering can proceed with reduced functionality.
Specifies the number of multisample samples used when rendering to this texture, controlling the level of anti-aliasing applied.

component.name: CubeMapTexture
component.summary: Cubemap texture assembled from six individual images, one for each face of a cube, used for environment mapping, reflections, and sky rendering.
component.details: Extends the base Texture class to support loading separate images for positive and negative axes of a 3D cube. This configuration allows for realistic spherical mapping in shaders, where texture coordinates are projected onto the cube faces for seamless omnidirectional sampling without seams or distortion at cube edges.
component.property: Path to the image file for the back face (negative Z-axis) of the cubemap.
Path to the image file for the front face (positive Z-axis) of the cubemap.
Path to the image file for the left face (negative X-axis) of the cubemap.
Path to the image file for the right face (positive X-axis) of the cubemap.
Path to the image file for the bottom face (negative Y-axis) of the cubemap.
Path to the image file for the top face (positive Y-axis) of the cubemap.

component.name: IOSurfaceTexture
component.summary: Texture created from a shared macOS IOSurface for zero-copy GPU data sharing.
component.details: Extends the base Texture class to bind an existing IOSurface as an OpenGL texture using GL_TEXTURE_RECTANGLE. Enables efficient inter-process or inter-context sharing of rendered images without CPU copying, suitable for compositing, video, or off-screen rendering pipelines.
component.property: The IOSurface identifier used to look up and bind the shared surface as a texture.

enums.name: FloatPrecision
enums.summary: Defines precision levels for floating-point operations in shader variables
enums.details: Controls the numerical precision of shader calculations. Higher precision improves accuracy but may reduce performance. Low precision is suitable for color values, Medium for texture coordinates, and High for positions and transformations.
enums.enum: No precision specified, may cause issues.
Lowest precision, typically 8-16 bits. Suitable for color values and non-critical calculations.
Medium precision, typically 16-24 bits. Ideal for texture coordinates and general-purpose calculations.
Highest precision, typically 32 bits. Required for vertex positions, matrices, and critical transformations.

enums.name: Shading
enums.summary: Defines shading models for lighting calculations in shaders
enums.details: Specifies the lighting algorithm used to calculate surface appearance. Each model offers different visual quality and performance characteristics. Unlit provides no lighting for flat colors or pre-lit textures, Phong offers classic specular highlights, and Standard implements physically-based rendering for realistic materials.
enums.enum: No lighting calculations applied. Renders surfaces with their base color and texture without any light interaction. Suitable for UI elements, emissive materials, or pre-baked lighting.
Classic Phong lighting model with ambient, diffuse, and specular components. Provides good performance with convincing highlights and shading for general-purpose 3D rendering.
Physically-based rendering (PBR) model. Provides realistic material appearance based on physical light interaction principles, supporting metallic and roughness workflows.

component.name: VertexShader
component.summary: Vertex processing stage of the shader pipeline
component.details: Processes each vertex of the geometry, transforming positions from model space to screen space. Handles per-vertex attributes and passes interpolated values to the fragment shader through shared variables.
component.property: GLSL shader language version number (e.g., 150 for GLSL 1.50, 330 for GLSL 3.30)
Default floating-point precision for vertex shader calculations
The lighting/shading model to use for vertex processing. Determines which lighting calculations are performed and how surface appearance is computed.

component.name: FragmentShader
component.summary: Fragment (pixel) processing stage of the shader pipeline
component.details: Executes for each pixel fragment, determining final color output. Samples textures, performs lighting calculations, and writes to the specified output variable. Receives interpolated values from the vertex shader.
component.property: GLSL shader language version number (e.g., 150 for GLSL 1.50, 330 for GLSL 3.30)
Default floating-point precision for fragment shader calculations
Name of the output variable for fragment color (e.g., "FragColor", "gl_FragColor")

module.component:
Complete shader program definition combining vertex and fragment stages Encapsulates the entire shader pipeline with configurable uniforms, attributes, and shared variables. Uniforms provide per-draw parameters (textures, colors, transforms), attributes supply per-vertex data (positions, UVs, colors), and shared variables pass interpolated data between shader stages. http://schemas.corepunch.com/orca/2006/xml/presentation
The default blending mode for the shader, controlling how rendered output combines with the existing framebuffer content. The default depth comparison function used for depth testing, determining which fragments are visible based on their depth values. Whether depth buffer writing is enabled by default. When true, rendered fragments update the depth buffer; when false, depth values are not written. BlendMode Compiled shader for runtime use

component.name: Mesh
component.summary: Renderable 3D geometry component with material and model data
component.details: Represents a 3D mesh object in the scene. Manages the geometry data (vertices, indices, normals, UVs) and associated material for rendering. Responds to lifecycle events for loading and cleanup of mesh resources.
component.property: Path or identifier to the mesh geometry file or resource. Specifies where to load the 3D model data from.
Reference to the material that defines the mesh's visual appearance. Controls shaders, textures, colors, and rendering properties applied to the geometry.
Name of the morph targets in the mesh
component.field: Internal pointer to the loaded model data structure containing the mesh geometry.

component.name: FontFamily
component.summary: TrueType font resource for text rendering
component.details: Loads and manages a TrueType font file for rendering text in the scene. Provides glyph data and metrics for text layout and rendering. May be extended in the future to support font families with variants (regular, bold, italic) similar to CSS font-family specifications.
component.handles: Called when the mesh component is initialized. Used to load the mesh geometry from the specified source and set up rendering resources.
Called when the mesh component is being destroyed. Used to clean up mesh data, release GPU buffers, and free associated resources.
